seize.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to take hold of something suddenly and violently
seize.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Maggie seized the letter from her.
seize.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people usually say grab or grab hold of rather than seize:
She grabbed hold of his hand.
seize.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to take control of a place suddenly and quickly, using military force
seize.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: A group of soldiers seized the airport.
seize.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if the police or government officers seize something, for example illegal drugs, they take legal possession of it
seize.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: 160,000 CDs were seized from illegal factories.
All of my assets were seized, including my home.
seize.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to suddenly catch someone and make sure they cannot get away
seize.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The gunmen were seized at 1 am.
seize.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if the police or another official authority seize goods or property, they take them because they are illegal or because the owner has not paid a debt
seize.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: South Korean authorities seized 186,000 fake products in 1999.
A warrant of execution allows a bailiff to seize sufficient goods to pay your debt and costs.
seize.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if the government or another authority seizes a company, it forces it to stop trading because of debts or illegal activities
seize.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The troubled insurance company was seized by regulators on April 11.
seize.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if you seize a chance or opportunity, you take advantage of it when it becomes available
seize.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Everyone in the organization should seize the initiative and improve their contribution.
Ohio has converted its technology to seize a share of the fast-growth $200 billion polymers industry.
